pros: This organisation has a clear vision and the funding to deliver it. Well resourced.
cons: The toxic culture at Common Seas comes right from the top (CEO). The most extreme and oppressive micro management that I have encountered in a long career. Staff are not trusted to perform their roles. If you question the frequent and erratic changes to priorities then you will be berated in team meetings. Incredibly demoralising.

review_title: Toxic culture and outdated working practices
pros: Huge potential, given its funding base. Staff that stick around are lovely but everyone has an eye on the exit.
cons: Common Seas is an exceptionally well-resourced organisation with no desire to create an environment which retains staff. What should be an enviable mission is unfortunately undermined by a culture of extreme micro-management. Productivity is mired by an endless stream of aggressive micro intrusions, which in turn erode agency and trust. Managing day-to-day programme operations involves staff asking each other what the CEO wanted that morning in order to avoid a public reprimand rather than what is best for the project. The team meetings are to be endured, and the ever-decreasing members of staff all share the same misgivings.

Has an extreme culture of micro-management. All decisions go through CEO so there is no autonomy. Very high staff turnover.

Think twice before leaving an existing role to join Common Seas.
